results.name: a(n) = n mod 6.
comment: The rightmost digit in the base-6 representation of n. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Jun 11 2007
[a(n) * a(m)] mod 6 == a(n*m mod 6) == a(n*m). - _Jon Perry_, Nov 11 2014
If n > 3 and (a(n) is in {0,2,3,4}), then n is not prime. - _Jean-Marc Rebert_, Jul 22 2015, corrected by _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 24 2015
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..65538
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,0,0,0,0,1).
formula: Complex representation: a(n) = (1/6) * (1 - r^n) * Sum_{k = 1..6} k * Product_{1 <= m < 6, m <> k} (1-r^(n-m)), where r = exp((Pi/3)*i) = (1 + sqrt(3)*i)/2 and i = sqrt(-1).
Trigonometric representation: a(n) = (16/3)^2 * (sin(n*Pi/6))^2 * Sum_{k = 1..6} k * Product_{1 <= m < 6, m<>k} (sin((n-m)*Pi/6))^2.
Also: g(x) = x*(5*x^6 - 6*x^5 + 1)/((1 - x^6)*(1 - x)^2). - _Hieronymus Fischer_, May 31 2007
a(n) = (n mod 3) + 3(floor(n/3) mod 2) = A010872(n) +3*A000035(A002264(n)). - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Jun 11 2007
